post_text: The Information Technology Department at Neshaminy has been very busy this summer preparing for their largest single deployment yet - over 3,500 devices will be distributed to families over the next two weeks. These Chromebooks and iPads will go to incoming students and those that did not get a device in the spring (such as siblings who shared a single device). The online Chromebook distribution system - modeled on that of a popular fast food chain - was designed by two Neshaminy IT interns (and NHS graduates), Andrew Schmitz and Steven Muller.

post_text: Congratulations to Neshaminy HS senior Maddie Tiemann, who took first place in the Virtual Pennsylvania Envirothon held this week. The multi-day competition is normally held outdoors at a central location, but this year was moved online with a series of daily competitions. More than 300 Envirothon participants representing 110 schools in 47 counties competed in this first-ever, weeklong, online Envirothon Challenge. During each day of the Challenge, individuals completed a 20-question quiz that focused on one of the five-station topics – Soils and Land Use, Current Issues, Wildlife, Aquatic Ecology, and Forestry. Out of a possible 500 overall points, Maddie earned 480 points to take the championship. Another NHS senior, Alex Ziegler, also made it to the state competition where she also earned a high score. Congratulations to Maddie, Alex, and Envirothon team co-advisors Jill Murray and Brian Suter on this remarkable accomplishment!

Staff members at Neshaminy High School and the three middle schools have been conducting locker clean-outs in a careful, organized manner. They are bagging items in plastic bags and making arrangements with each family for a "socially-distanced" pick-up BY APPOINTMENT ONLY.
Please know that we are striving to reunite as many locker contents with their owners as possible. This is being carried out in order of necessity (NHS seniors, 8th grade students, etc.) to ensure that students graduating or moving up to a new building get their belongings first.
We ask for your patience as we move through this process for other grades. You will be contacted by one of the secretaries at your child's school when it is your turn to pick up your child's locker or desk contents.
We do not have a schedule of dates for pick-ups from various grades, but please know that we are doing our very best to complete this process for as many students as possible, as quickly as possible.

post_text: Today we are happy to highlight some of our Covid-19 frontline heroes who are not working in healthcare settings, but are nonetheless vital to supporting us during this pandemic. Keith Kling, who retired from the US Navy, graduated NHS in 1984 and is the Postmaster in Spencer, NC. Mark McClune is a 2016 graduate working as an associate at Sam's Club. Andrew Silcox wrote to say, "I’m a Class of 2006 NHS grad working as a truck driver for FedEx and a volunteer firefighter in Midway, Georgia (previously served at the Langhorne-Middletown Fire Company). We’ve been hauling a significant amount of medical equipment and protective gear in addition to food, drinks and every day supplies since the beginning. Balancing both the volunteer service and trucking has been a challenge, but it’s one we accept helping to keep the country fed, stocked, clothed and fire-free." Thank you to all our essential workers out on the front lines every day!

post_text: Tonight at the Neshaminy School Board meeting, Dr. Robert McGee was unanimously approved as the next Superintendent of Neshaminy School District, effective July 1, 2020 for a contract term of five years. Dr. McGee is a Neshaminy District native and a graduate of the former Maple Point High School. His 33-year career at Neshaminy includes 20 years as a math teacher starting in 1987 at Carl Sandburg Middle School. Since then, he has served as an Instructional Coach, Assistant Principal and Principal at Neshaminy High School. He has held his current position as Director of Secondary Education for the District since 2018. Dr. McGee will replace Joseph Jones III, who will be leaving on June 30 to return to the classroom as a teacher in the Philadelphia School District. Congratulations, Dr. McGee!

Good morning! Welcome to Day 1 of the "vacation" that none of us wanted. We sincerely thank all of our Neshaminy families and staff for their patience and understanding as we move through these uncharted waters. Though our classrooms and offices will be empty for at least the next couple of weeks, our administrative and curriculum staff is working remotely to develop resource lists, meal distribution procedures, and plans to continue the school year once this crisis has abated.

We will be communicating those plans and resources to our families and staff through our email / text / phone alert system AND on the District website. Our main information page during this shutdown is WWW.NESHAMINY.ORG/COVID-19, where you will be able to find update archives along with links to any resources that we publish.

We know this situation raises a lot of questions and we'll do our best to answer them as soon as we have the information we need to do so.

Have a great weekend, stay safe, and now go wash your hands! 👏☄️
